results.name: Triangle T(n,k) (n>=0, 0 <= k <= n) read by rows giving number of underdiagonal lattice paths from (0,0) to (n,k) using only steps R=(1,0), V=(0,1) and D=(1,2).
comment: For another interpretation of this array see the Example section.

N. J. A. Sloane, Illustration of the initial terms of the U(n,k) array
formula: Define T(0,0)=1 and T(n,k)=0 for k<0 and k >n. Then the array is generated by the recurrence T(n,k) = T(n,k-1) + T(n-1,k) + T(n-1,k-2). For example, T(5,3) = 46 = T(5,2) + T(4,3) + T(4,1) = 18 + 24 + 4. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 28 2013
example: T(3,2)=7 because we have RRRVV, RRVRV, RRVVR, RVRRV, RVRVR, RRD and RDR.
Equivalently, let U(n,k) (for n >= 0, 0 <= k <= n) be the number of walks from (0,0) to (n,k) using steps (1,1), (1,-1) and (0,-1). Then U(n,n-k) = T(n,k). The U(n,k) array begins:
The recurrence for this version is: U(0,0)=1, U(n,k)=0 for k>n or k<0; U(n,k) = U(n,k+1) + U(n-1,k+1) + U(n,k-1). E.g. 46 = 18 + 4 + 24. Also U(n,0) = A052709(n-1).
